ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basic grammar structures of Korean. In a lot of ways, going into this course I wanted my speaking to improve but didn't care as much about my writing despite the fact that this is what the course is historically geared towards. Nevertheless, I found that my Korean improved greatly throughout the semester in every way.
Korean writing
I improved my Korean writing skills and expanded my knowledge of Korean grammar.
How to write more in Korean and grammar

Basic Korean grammar and vocabulary. Through this course, I greatly improved my Korean writing skills and also worked on my speaking and reading. I can now write paragraphs using proper Korean grammar.
Communication, writing, spelling
I learned more Korean writing and speaking skills.
I learned how to speak more comfortably and fluently in Korean, and my Korean writing ability improved greatly. I also now know how to read quickly as well.

Basic skills in reading, writing, and speaking
Korean vocabulary and grammar
a better korean ability

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is quite disorganized at the moment but I got what I needed out of it (improving my Korean).
Professor Choi is funny and I enjoy her personality. However she is not the best at teaching and can be unorganized.

Strength: The class was very homework oriented and helped with reviewing the content we learned for that specific day.
Weakness: The module for our semester assignment was outdated and confusing, causing it to be difficult to locate homework. I would recommend creating a weekly newsletter on canvas for assignments.

Strengths: intensive; quick and noticeable improvement as long as you kept up with the lessons; choi ssn was always diligent with giving feedback on your work and was quick to grade assignments and tests
Weaknesses: the class schedule was a bit difficult to follow; due dates for assignments and quiz dates were unclear sometimes
It is fine at the beginning but it is so disorganized that it feels weird and as if what we are learning isnt cohesive

Strengths: improved Korean skills, particularly writing; provides many opportunities for practice in order to solidify understanding; taught in Korean and often engage in conversation in Korean with other heritage speaker; Seiyoung Kim is an amazing, supportive TA!!
Weakness: a bit disorganized, sometimes unclear which assignments are due and when
Strengths: Group projects

Strengths include learning a lot of vocabulary and quickly becoming more familiar with Korean, and weaknesses include unorganized homework and project deadlines, as well as not knowing sometimes what tests were going to occur.

Strengths: having the opportunity to practice speaking in conversation every day, constant feedback
Weaknesses: the course was a bit disorganized in that assignments and instructions were sometimes unclear

Typically, work is assigned daily which makes it difficult to keep up with the courseload at some points in the semester. However, since this class occurs every day, it is easy to see personal growth in learning.

strengths is that she starts from the basics, but weaknesses is that there is a wide range of abilities all in one class. there really needs to be an L1 and L2 heritage korean class. I often felt behind other students and the large class size made me not want to ask questions or speak up. this class sort of assumes you are fluent in listening and speaking and focuses more on reading and writing. I was neither. also, the class was not well organized. i was often confused about deadlines and assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I totally would. As a heritage speaker, I benefitted greatly from this course to improve my foundational Korean.
If interested in Korean writing, yes.
Yes, but I would recommend it to students who already have a good grasp on the Korean language.
Yes if you are a heritage speaker with a basic intuitive grasp of Korean.
Yes, but only if you are truly a heritage speaker and know something about writing

Yes! Although the class can be a bit difficult or disorganized at times, I greatly improved my Korean skills and met amazing classmates. This class fits heritage speakers who can speak and understand Korean decently but wish to learn formal grammar rules and vocabulary.
Yes, I would really recommend this course if you are looking to improve your Korean skills!
Yes, if you are a heritage speaker, it is a great environment and opportunity to improve basic skills in speaking, reading, and writing
only if you are already comfortable with your korean speaking and listening ability.
